entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-20

Daily report: [2019-01-20 Sun]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 3:48
File time 3:48
Today’s Tasks 3:08
  CS5001 3:08
TODO     CS5001 - Homework #2 3:08
DONE       Initial review of homework programming problems 0:25
DONE       Setting up environment 0:15
DONE       Programming #1 1:38
NEXT       Programming #2 0:50
Morning Ritual 0:40
TODO   Journal writing 0:23
TODO   Review agenda and calendar 0:17

Summary

Dedicated time today to CS5001. Starting my initial review of programming problems from the homework, completing defining the functions and almost complete with the test cases and preparing for the last portion of the assignment where I’m putting it all together.

Problem

Estimating the amount of time it takes to complete a task. Sometimes I may allocate 30min or so for a given task and then I’m consumed by the task and want to spend more time with it and then not dedicating enough time for other tasks.The proper optimal distribution of times for a given task to push a brick forward.

Insight

Before starting a task I estimate the amount of time it will take me to complete the given task. This deliberate planning of estimating my time and logging has kept me focused and accountable.

Tomorrow

To finish writing test cases for the programming component #2. To complete programming problem #3 for CS5001. To dedicate time tomorrow to review this week’s material for CS5002. To complete all of the problems for CS5002 and get started on the Zybook reading.

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Initial review of homework programming problems

  • DONE Setting up environment

  • DONE Programming #1

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-17

Daily report: [2019-01-17 Thu]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 4:23
File time 4:23
Today’s Tasks 3:16
TODO   CS5001 0:50
DONE     Prepare CS5001 homework for submission 0:50
TODO   CS5002 1:41
DONE     Prepare CS5002 homework for submission 1:41
WAITING   Apply for GradPlus loans for 2019-2020 0:42
DONE   Send email to MD about financial aid 0:03
Morning Ritual 1:07
TODO   Meditation 0:11
TODO   Shower 0:23
TODO   Breakfast 0:33

Summary

I finalized the submission of my first homework assignment for both of my classes. Dedicated time to finalizing financial aid and reviewing for today’s lab session.

Problem

For CS5001, I allocated some time this morning making sure style was correct, test cases, and generally good for submission. A good chunk of time trying to setup latex to play nicely with emacs. I was able to get it working but couldn’t get the completion engine, company, to work with the latex symbols. I’m going to try this again at some point in the future so I’m able to submit my homework assignments digitally. I experienced some difficulty with the financial aid office and I’m waiting to hear back.

Insight

To start homework assignments earlier and focus on completing them. I will start using emacs to calculate the amount of effort it takes to complete a given task.

Doing Despite Disliking: Self-regulatory Strategies in Everyday Aversive Activities

Abstract: We investigated the self-regulatory strategies people spontaneously use in their everyday lives to regulate their persistence during aversive activities. In pilot studies (pooled N = 794), we identified self-regulatory strategies from self-reports and generated hypotheses about individual differences in trait self-control predicting their use. Next, deploying ambulatory assessment (N = 264, 1940 reports of aversive/challenging activities), we investigated predictors of the strategies’self-reported use and effectiveness (trait self-control and demand types). The popularity of strategies varied across demands. In addition, people higher in trait self-control were more likely to focus on the positive consequences of a given activity, set goals, and use emotion regulation. Focusing on positive consequences, focusing on negative consequences (of not performing the activity), thinking of the near finish, and emotion regulation increased perceived self-regulatory success across demands, whereas distracting oneself from the aversive activity decreased it. None of these strategies, however, accounted for the beneficial effects of trait self-control on perceived self-regulatory success. Hence, trait self-control and strategy use appear to represent separate routes to good self-regulation. By considering trait- and process-approaches these findings promote a more comprehensive understanding of self-regulatory success and failure during people’s daily attempts to regulate their persistence. © 2018 European Association of Personality Psychology

Tomorrow

To review this week’s material from both CS5001 and CS5001 classes and to marinate the homework released for each class.

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Prepare homework for submission

    • State “DONE” from “NEXT” [2019-01-17 Thu 08:11]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-16 Wed 17:41]

  • DONE Send email to MD about financial aid

    • State “DONE” from “NEXT” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:48]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:45]

  • DONE Prepare CS5002 homework for submission

    • State “DONE” from “NEXT” [2019-01-17 Thu 14:04]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:33]

  • DONE Review this week’s material CS5001

    • State “DONE” from “NEXT” [2019-01-17 Thu 22:08]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:34]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:33]

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-16

Daily report: [2019-01-16 Wed]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 3:01
File time 3:01
Today’s Tasks 1:18
DONE   CS5001 0:38
DONE     Homework #1 [5⁄5] 0:38
DONE       Programming #3 - change.py 0:38
DONE   Swimming at the YMCA 0:40
This Week’s Projects 1:20
DONE   Meeting with ER 0:12
DONE   Appointment with JB 1:08
Morning Ritual 0:08
TODO   Breakfast 0:08
Afternoon Ritual 0:15
TODO   Recovery Block 0:15

Summary

Woke up early to the YMCA to swim and had two meetings with my health care providers. I re-looked at change.py and was able to come up with a working solution in the afternoon. Then later had night classes.

Problem

change.py took some time to work on while the other homework problems I was able to complete in a moderately fast time. I believe the lesson learned here, it’s not quite about speed, but focusing more on planning and making sure I have a draft on paper before I start my second draft on a computer. In addition, I realized that I was feeling exhausted the whole day at different times by the time late afternoon arrived.

Insight

When working on a programming problem, regardless of how easy I may perceive the problem to be, start on paper first to at least have an idea. Other thoughts are to possibly change my morning routine so I’m not waking up at 6am everyday, but perhaps the night I have classes I can wake up later.

Tomorrow

To review homework before submission for both classes and review material from CS5001 in preparation for lab

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Swimming at the YMCA

  • DONE Appointment with JB

  • DONE Appointment with JB

  • DONE Programming #3 - change.py

  • DONE Meeting with ER

  • DONE Written #1

  • DONE Written #2

  • DONE Written #3

  • DONE Written #4

  • DONE Homework #1 [5⁄5]

  • DONE CS5001 :5001:

  • DONE CS5002 :5002:

  • DONE Review using supplemental material

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-15

Daily report: [2019-01-15 Tue]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 5:43
File time 0:28
File time 5:15
Today’s Tasks 3:51
TODO   CS5001 2:30
TODO     Homework #1 [2⁄7] 2:30
NEXT       Programming #3 - change.py 2:30
TODO   CS5002 1:21
DONE     Zybook Reading 1:21
Morning Ritual 0:36
TODO   Meditation 0:11
TODO   Journal writing 0:15
TODO   Review agenda and calendar 0:10
Bedtime Ritual 0:48
TODO   Admin Block 0:32
TODO   Create functional space 0:16

Summary

Spent the majority of today working on change.py and completing the Zybook reading. I was able to complete the Zybook reading and make progress on change.py. There was some level of friction due to not starting this specific problem on paper.

Problem

Part of the difficulty that I noticed in completing change.py was that I didn’t first attempt to solve it on a piece of paper, but rather jumped into emacs and tried to solve it. Doing it this approach took me a much longer time than anticipated.

Insight

Make sure I have a general schema, outline, notes, worked out the solution somewhat on paper and then on a computer. Using a computer and programming it is equivalent to a second or third draft of writing, in this case code.

Tomorrow

Will take time to review the problem, review test cases, syntax and general style. Will see if I have the time to do office hours.

For CS5002 I will use supplementary sources to review material and in preparation for the upcoming lecture.

entry.title: Accountability
entry.content:
While I was hospitalized for close to two years, the first trip that I made to society was to visit Northeastern University in one of their college tours for prospective students. At the time when I was hospitalized, I was learning Python, and I didn’t have reliable access to a computer. In times I didn’t have access to a computer, I printed pages from a PDF and took notes on scratch paper that nurses gave me.

I feel immense pride to say years later I was accepted to Northeastern University. I’m honored to be the first in my family to be admitted to graduate school. I’m a neurodivergent, person of color, Latino pursuing my master’s degree in Computer Science. With all that being said I have not done well in my graduate classes. I was unaware of the level of rigor required for the program while also working full-time as a high school teacher compounded with life’s challenge’s and my own habits, emotions and insecurities.

In this website, I will document my learning path and my process to hold myself accountable for reaching my goal of attaining my master’s degree in Computer Science.

  • In the Now section you can see my objectives for today, this week, month and year.
  • The Review section consists of a daily and weekly review, a micro-level look at my day including time stamps and a table with a summary of time spent on a given task.
  • The Courses section will contain courses that I am currently taking or have in the past with links to notes taken on the topics presented in the class.
  • The Notes section consists of my notes taken about a subject matter. The notes will be used to create lessons to be made accessible to a broader audience.

If you have any comments or suggestions, please feel free to contact me.

entry.title: Graduate School
entry.content:
I’m a graduate student at Northeastern University’s ALIGN program pursuing a master’s degree in Computer Science. The ALIGN program consists of a series of bridge courses for graduate students who didn’t major in Computer Science in their undergraduate studies. Upon completion of the ALIGN program students begin taking graduate level classes in computer science.

Attaining a master’s degree in computer science will link my community experience with technology and leverage this knowledge to contribute to the self-development and self-sufficiency of communities of color, as well as to enhance people’s capacities to solve problems. My long-term goal is to create a co-operative of social justice focused technologists, “Technology for Communities”, which specializes in civic technology to assist community organizations by assessing needs, analyzing data and creating solutions. A computer science degree combined with my collective experience as a community organizer will allow me to use technology collaboratively with organizations and individuals to address needs to strengthen communities and amplify our collective voice.

entry.title: Game Over! Continue?
entry.content:
From about 2012 to 2014 I was hospitalized due to my mental health. This period was one of the most painful and challenging times for me in my life: being away from friends, family, and society. I was completely excluded from participating in society both physically and mentally, an outcast. I longed to walk in the city, to see my friends and family, to continue my education and to be involved in a community. Upon my release in 2014, I had to restart my life.

I reconnected with friends and started volunteering in different non-profits in the Boston area. My efforts in volunteering eventually lead me to the opportunity of being an AmeriCorps member for United Way. I along with others focused on providing services to residents in Lynn, MA. In my year of service, I served at a high school: supporting students and teachers, creating an afterschool program, being a positive role model and providing support and services to the community. Around the same period, I found out about Resilient Coders. I decided to volunteer in their afterschool program that teaches youth from communities in the Boston area how to code. Fast forward to the present, and I have worked for two years as a technology teacher at a high school in Boston and was accepted into Northeastern’s Master’s program in computer science.

As a Latino, activist, mental health advocate and technologist, I have learned you must have a systematic understanding of problems and issues that affect organizations, communities, and individuals, to leverage technology as a tool for social change. I am deeply passionate about exploring the use of technology to address the lack of access and inequity in education, health, and unemployment in communities of color.

entry.title: Humble Beginnings
entry.content:
My beginnings with technology start in early childhood. During the weekends I visited my father and spent most of the time with my brother Robinson. Robinson, an electrical engineer from the Dominican Republic, was my mentor and role-model. When I visited during the weekend, I would find my brother taking apart and repairing different devices. I looked forward to spending time with him, and I would ask questions about technology, such as “What is RAM?”, “What are the differences between AMD and Intel?”. As a child, exposure to my brother’s work was a valuable resource that expanded my knowledge, sparked my curiosity and interest in technology. As my skills developed, I later assisted my brother in disassembling computers, running diagnostics, installing and upgrading software.

I then attended Middle School, and a science professor was discarding a computer. I seized this opportunity and asked if I could have it, the professor donated the desktop to me. This was my first computer. I carried the large desktop up a hill and walked several blocks to my house. I troubleshot the desktop and identified the power supply wasn’t working. I swapped the power supply from an abandoned computer, and voila, I became the proud owner of a Pentium II 233 MHz Desktop Computer.

Through this computer and my 56K modem, I had the world’s knowledge at my fingertips. My mind was free to explore my interests unhindered from physical and economic barriers. Having a computer enabled me to excel in my studies compared to my peers who didn’t have access to one. Around the same time, I entered a summer program for Middle School students to take advanced classes and prepare them for high school level work. One of the mentors in the program offered to buy a book from a Barnes and Nobles bookstore. As the years progressed, I learned more about computers, increased my knowledge of technology and about the world.

From my experience, having access to technology or resources, advanced my learning potential. By the time I entered high school, the skills I had gained proved to be invaluable. I credit having access to a computer at a young age and having supportive mentors in shaping my path on being a self-learner. After graduating high school, I entered college to understand the problems that impact my communities, and I majored in Political Science with minors in Philosophy and Latin American Studies.

entry.title: CS5001: Intensive Foundations of Computer Science
entry.content: This course is an accelerated introduction to computer science with the Python programming language.

entry.title: CS5002: Discrete and Data Structures
entry.content: This course introduces the mathematical structures and methods that form the foundation of computer science.

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Over the years after many conversations with friends about niche topics, staying up late at night pondering life on the verge of an existential crisis, we have arrived here… a blog in 2019? Bueno, mejor que nada… This post is titled ‘Hello World’, it symbolizes the first step we take to attempt to communicate with someone or something else while being simultaneously born into a new digital world of our creation.

I want you to step into my world and I’ll take you with me on this journey of pursuing my master’s degree in Computer Science. I see Computer Science as attaining a new ability to be able to see the world through a computational lens, the opportunity to creatively solve problems and to contribute, create and share knowledge with others.

This blog, this world that’s being created will serve as a repository about what I’m currently learning. I intend to share what I’ve learned with others by creating content that’s accessible to a wider audience. As someone who in the past has been deeply involved with community-building as a former community organizer, teacher, and mentor, I seek to bridge technology and social justice. I expect this journey to be filled with moments of joy, tears, and frustration… Pa’lante!
